title: Can I disagree with an essay question? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. I instruct my students that they may disagree with the focusing statement of the essay question. “Be always sure you are right - then go ahead.” - Davy Crockett (Davy Crockett Quotes) One does not have to sincerely disagree with the position, but one has to have strong evidence to make a clear, concise and correct rebuttal. Have sufficient evidence to back the position. Using a “yes, but…” strategy can be very effective: Yes, Columbus navigated poorly, but…” Give credit to the position stated in the essay question, but then demonstrate the flaws of the position. The contraposition can be a defensible one, but it is a greater challenge. Yes, but the greater the challenge, the sweeter the rewards.

Certainly, you can. If your instructor/teacher/educator/grader is in any way competent they ought to encourage you to do so. Disagreement is what makes thoughts interesting. However, before you write an essay disagreeing with the premises of your prompt be certain you've got the details right. If “x is clearly false”, for example, it would only be prudent to very carefully determine why that claim is being made. You'll come across quite silly if you're disagreeing with a well established fact and you can't disprove it.

Yes, you can. I think the instructor might be looking for someone to do precisely what you are intending. As long as you believe you can make the case for your position, go for it. If a question rests on a false premise, you should point it out. You risk becoming known as an original thinker.
